misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also “carry along” or automatically rearrange the corresponding names array, so that the name at index n-1 still matches the highest score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. `Arrays.sort(b)` reorders only the elements of `b` (scores). It does not and cannot automatically reorder `a` (names). After sorting, the indices in `a` and `b` no longer refer to the same student unless you explicitly swap both arrays in tandem during a custom sort, or you sort a combined structure (e.g., `Student{name, score}` objects).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the last-entered name (a[n-1]) paired with the highest score (b[n-1]), which may be a mismatched student.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(b) on the scores array will automatically keep the names array synchronized with the scores, such that when scores are sorted, the corresponding names will move with them in parallel.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort() only sorts the array it's called on. It does not affect other arrays. When the student sorts the scores array, the names array remains in its original order. The student has confused the behavior of sorting a single array with the behavior of sorting a data structure that maintains relationships between parallel arrays (like a 2D array or custom objects with comparable fields).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will print incorrect name-score pairs. For example, with input names [Alice, Bob, Charlie] and scores [85, 92, 78], after sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the code will print 'Top student: Charlie (92)' because it accesses a[n-1] (which is still Charlie) and b[n-1] (which is now 92), rather than the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet:
String[] a=new String[n];
int[] b=new int[n];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the arrays 'a' and 'b' were populated at the same indices to represent single entities (student names and scores), Java will maintain this logical link even when one of the arrays is sorted. They assume that moving a value in 'b' during a sort operation will automatically move the corresponding value in 'a'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java execution model, arrays are independent objects stored at different memory addresses. Methods like Arrays.sort() operate exclusively on the single array object passed as an argument. There is no implicit or 'reactive' link between two separate arrays regardless of how the programmer intends to use them.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: “Sorting one array also reorders its parallel partner” (parallel-arrays coupling misconception)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array is implicitly kept in sync (or that `a[n-1]` will now refer to the name of whoever has the highest score).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(b)` only rearranges the elements of array `b`. The `names` array `a` is a separate object and is not automatically permuted. With parallel arrays, you must swap both arrays together during sorting (or sort indices/objects). After sorting only `b`, `a[n-1]` is simply the last-entered name, not the name associated with `b[n-1]`.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the highest score correctly, but often prints the wrong student name (the name in the last input position).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort one of two parallel arrays, the other array will automatically stay synchronized with it. They think that the index-based pairing between names and scores is somehow preserved at a deeper level, even though only one array is explicitly sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects with no implicit binding. Sorting array `b` rearranges only the scores; array `a` remains unchanged. The student's mental model incorrectly assumes that the arrays have some automatic linking mechanism that would keep corresponding elements aligned after sorting one array. In reality, sorting parallel arrays requires either: (1) sorting both together (e.g., using indices to swap both), or (2) using a data structure that maintains the relationship (like an array of objects or a map).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program prints the wrong name paired with the highest score. With sample input (Alice/85, Bob/92, Charlie/78), after sorting only the scores array to [78, 85, 92], the code prints 'Top student: Charlie (92)' because it takes the last element of each array. However, Charlie's actual score is 78, not 92. The program should print 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays are used to store related data (parallel arrays), the computer maintains an inherent link between indices across both arrays. Consequently, they believe that a built-in operation like sorting on one array will automatically synchronize or 'carry' the corresponding elements of the other array to maintain the data pairs.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that arrays are independent memory structures. In Java, the 'parallel' nature of arrays exists only in the programmer's logic, not in the execution model. The Arrays.sort() method operates exclusively on the memory addresses belonging to the array passed as an argument and has no awareness of or access to other arrays.
